message: I hope everyone had a safe and enjoyable time ringing in 2017. Share if you're looking forward to what's in store for our country this year under a unified Republican government.

It's an exciting day here at our nation's Capitol. As we kick off the new session of Congress, I'm humbled for the opportunity to continue being the voice in Washington for the Northeast Texans I represent. And beyond this, I'm looking forward to working with a unified Republican government to finally deliver on our conservative solutions to the biggest issues impacting folks back home.

Just one day after Republicans in Congress launched our renewed efforts to repeal Obamacare, President Obama made his way to Capitol Hill in an attempt to defend his disastrous law. But the facts still stand: under Obamacare, premiums and deductibles have skyrocketed, patient choice has been depleted, and people have been kicked off their plans. No matter how much Democrats and the Obama administration deny it, this law needs to go. It's time to make way for our conservative solutions that will put the American people back in charge of their own healthcare.

BREAKING: Today I voted for, and the House passed, the Midnight Rules Relief Act, which enables Congress to wipe out Obama's last-minute regulations swiftly before their damage is done.   The slew of regulations being churned out in the Obama administration's final days represents the exact type of executive overreach the American people just voted resoundingly against. These regulations – which carry the weight of law – have a massive impact on Americans' lives, and we in Congress owe it to the citizens of this great country to stop this madness.

BREAKING: Today I voted for, and the House passed, legislation to condemn and reverse the UN’s anti-Israel resolution the Obama administration refused to veto last month.  Immediately after the Obama administration allowed the UN to pass its anti-Israel resolution, I joined my colleagues in Congress to express my grave concerns about this drastic deviation from America’s longstanding policy of defending our ally, Israel, from such one-sided actions.   Today’s vote solidifies our strong stance against the Obama administration’s shameful refusal to stand up on behalf of our most trusted ally in the Middle East, and it lays the foundation for the incoming Trump administration to move swiftly and forcefully to address the negative impact of this irresponsible decision.

IT'S OFFICIAL: This afternoon, the election of Donald Trump for president of the United States was certified in a Joint Session of Congress. I'm certainly looking forward to what's in store for our great country following his inauguration in just two short weeks.

This week, my fellow Texan and friend, Rep. Sam Johnson, announced his plan to retire at the end of 2018. Beyond his conservative efforts as a member of the U.S. House, his service in the Air Force and resilience after being held as a prisoner of war in Vietnam have left an unforgettable mark on our country. It’s been quite an honor to serve alongside him for the past two years in Congress, and he will be greatly missed.

Today, on National Law Enforcement Appreciation Day, Americans across the country are coming together to say thank you for the selfless dedication of our brave men and women in blue. Last year, 135 law enforcement officers lost their lives in the line of duty – a sacrifice we must never take for granted.  As a Member of Congress, I’m committed to continuing my efforts to ensure our law enforcement officers have the tools and equipment they need to defend themselves as they fight to keep us safe. After all, it's the least we can do in return for the great risks they take on our behalf every single day.

The Clemson Tigers weren't the only Tigers to win it all this football season. The Gunter High School Tigers from right here in Texas' 4th District just took home a state football championship title, and official celebrations were held today at the Grayson County Court House.   I'm glad a member of my staff was able to attend to present the team with a flag flown over the U.S. Capitol in their honor, and I'm looking forward to displaying the signed helmet they've presented to me in my Washington, D.C. office to commemorate this huge victory.

BREAKING: The House just took major action to drain the "regulatory swamp" that's grown for eight years under President Obama's watch – and we did it by passing two of my bills that were actually inspired by you: the Separation of Powers Restoration Act and the ALERT Act, which were both included in the Regulatory Accountability Act we voted on this evening.  Ever since I've been in Congress, I’ve heard a resounding message from the folks I’m proud to represent: they’re fed up with the bureaucratic overreach they've been forced to endure for too long. Now, with President-elect Trump about to take office, I'm incredibly optimistic that our efforts to get the government back to working FOR the American people will actually be signed into law.

I just spoke LIVE with The Daily Signal about my legislation that passed the House yesterday to rein in bureaucratic overreach and the Republican plan to wipe out Obama’s onslaught of last-minute regulations. We’re wasting no in launching our aggressive efforts to partner with President-elect Trump to drain the “regulatory swamp.”

ICYMI: This week, the U.S. House passed two of my bills to help drain the “regulatory swamp” bred during the Obama Presidency: the Separation of Powers Restoration Act and the ALERT Act.   These bills don’t only clean up the mess left behind by President Obama’s swath of unelected bureaucrats, but they also seek to ensure that such a huge outpouring of burdensome regulations won’t be allowed to happen ever again.

THIS JUST IN: The U.S. House just passed legislation to officially launch Congress' renewed Obamacare repeal efforts. With President-elect set to take office in just a few days, I’m glad we’ve advanced this critical step through both the House and Senate to set stage for the full repeal and stable transition that’s soon to come.   I was proud to vote for this important measure on behalf of all the individuals who’ve lost their coverage, and on behalf of all the families that were forced to pay skyrocketing premiums they simply can’t afford thanks to this disaster of a law. The American people have made it clear that it’s time to say goodbye to this burdensome pile of broken promises, and now we’re going to deliver on this demand.

I'd like to congratulate Amanda Zabolotny on her recent selection to become a pilot upon her graduation from the U.S. Naval Academy. Amanda is a graduate of Rockwall-Heath High School and is currently the head cheerleader at the U.S. Naval Academy. Her prestigious accomplishments and her dedication to serving our country certainly make Texas' 4th District proud.

ICYMI: Last week I voted for, and the U.S. House passed, a waiver to allow retired Gen. James Mattis to serve as Defense secretary in the Trump administration.   As a former federal terrorism prosecutor, I'm glad that President-elect Trump picked a proven leader for this important position who actually recognizes our enemies at face value. Gen. Mattis' tough track record proves he clearly understands the robust military presence our country needs to defeat those, like Iran, who refuse to play by the rules.

This weekend, I was glad to see events being held all across Texas' 4th District in honor of Martin Luther King Jr. and the legacy he left behind. America will be forever inspired by his unwavering commitment to peace and democracy as he shaped our nation's history.

I'm glad that my dear colleague and friend, Rep. Trey Gowdy, is joining the House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence. His incredible dedication to justice has been made more than clear by his devout leadership of the Benghazi investigations and through his service on the House Judiciary Committee. I'm certainly looking forward to what he'll do in this new role as he seeks to ensure our nation's intelligence activities are in line with the Constitution and U.S. law.

President Obama’s decision to commute Chelsea Manning’s remaining prison sentence shows – yet again – an alarming refusal to put national security ahead of politics.   Allowing anyone who’s exposed our nation’s most sensitive information to get off easy certainly isn’t how we prevent Americans’ safety from being jeopardized again. We simply can't afford to play games with anyone who's engaged in such treachery.

State and local law enforcement officers from all over Texas’ 4th District and across the country were rightfully outraged at President Obama’s actions to limit their access to live-saving defense equipment, and I've already spoken to President-elect Tump's team about taking swift action to restore access to the tools they need to safely do their jobs. With the enormous sacrifices our nation’s law enforcement officers make on our behalf, we owe them nothing less than the very best protective equipment we can offer.

ICYMI: Today President-elect Trump participated in a wreath-laying ceremony at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier. I'm certainly glad to see our nation's veterans being honored as the 2017 Inauguration events are officially underway.

President Trump’s inauguration represents the start of a new chapter in our nation’s history – a chapter I am confident will be far different from the malaise we’ve seen during the past eight years under President Obama. Under our now unified Republican government, we can finally prove why the conservative policies we’ve been fighting for all along are truly what we need to get our country back on track.     It’s time to do away with Obama’s failed liberal progressive experiment that has made our country less prosperous, less safe, and less secure. We’ve already paved a clear path for Obamacare repeal, cutting back on excessive red tape, restoring respect for the Constitution, cracking down on illegal immigration, and boosting our national security. I’m looking forward to partnering with President Trump to advance all of these important priorities, so we can Make America Great Again.

It was such an incredible honor to witness today's peaceful transition of power as Donald J. Trump was officially inaugurated as the 45th President of the United States.   As President Trump said in his speech, today's ceremony had special meaning because we aren't just transferring power from one administration to another, we are transferring power from Washington, D.C. and giving it back to you, the people.

I'm so glad my beautiful wife and daughters could join me in Washington yesterday to welcome in our new president. It was great having them by my side as we celebrated such a special day in our nation's history.

I wasn't the only resident from Texas' 4th District in Washington for President Trump's inauguration on Friday. Amanda Zabolotny of Heath, Texas marched with the United States Naval Academy during the official Inaugural Parade as Trump made his was from the Capitol to the White House. What an incredible honor.

I was honored to be featured in the Washington Examiner today for my efforts in Congress to fight bureaucratic overreach and intrusive federal regulations.   With President Trump now in office, the impossible becomes possible. For the first time in eight long years, we've got the momentum we need to push the truly conservative, limited-government policies I've been fighting for on your behalf all the way across the finish line. I'm extremely optimistic for what lies ahead.

I applaud Gov. Abbott's unwavering refusal to tolerate sanctuary city policies in the State of Texas. It's simple: we are a nation of laws, and we've got to ensure we enforce the rules that are already on the books. This is precisely why the Stop Dangerous Sanctuary Cities Act (H.R.400) was one of the very first bills I cosponsored in the new session of Congress, and I look forward to working with President Trump to finally put a stop to unlawful practice across the entire country.

I'd like to congratulate the Commerce High School cheerleading team on their historic victory at the UIL State Spirit Championships. This marks the first-ever state cheerleading title in the school's 100-year-plus history. The students of Texas' 4th District certainly never fail to impress me with their diverse array of high accomplishments.

Today I voted for the No Taxpayer Funding for Abortion Act (H.R. 7), which passed the U.S. House to permanently protect taxpayer dollars from being used to fund abortions through government programs.   Past legislation of this nature has already saved 2 million American lives over the past 40 years, and I'm proud to uphold our moral obligation to save millions more in the decades to come.

Remember Obama's so-called "Clean Power Plan" that threatened to jack up energy costs for Texas families and eliminate American jobs?  Just as I said when I voted against this disastrous action – this is exactly what you get when policies are created solely for the sake of advancing a radical agenda on climate change. I’m so glad we now have a president who is committed to putting the American people first instead.

I'm glad President Trump is wasting no time getting to work on fulfilling his commitment to strengthening our national border security. It's about time America sends a clear signal to the world that we will no longer tolerate the ongoing violation of our immigration laws. After all – the safety of our citizens and the protection of our homeland depend on it.

I'm very encouraged by the thousands of folks who gathered in our nation's capital today for the 43rd annual March for Life. This incredible outpouring of support for life at all stages reinforces why I voted just last week to permanently extend the Hyde Amendment's ban on federal funds from being used to fund abortion.   I've already joined more than 100 of my pro-life colleagues in formally calling President Trump and Vice President Pence to help us in advancing the rights of unborn children and their mothers, and I'm optimistic about the support we'll receive from them on this important effort moving forward.

I applaud President Trump's actions to vamp up the vetting of refugees attempting to enter our country. As a member of the House Homeland Security Committee, I've been very vocal about the threats posed by the woeful inadequacy of our current screening process – because there's simply too much at stake to allow individuals with terrorist ties to slip through the cracks.   Similar to the American SAFE Act I voted for in the last session of Congress, Trump's executive orders on this issue seek to ensure America remains a beacon of freedom to the world and a land of safety and security. In order to fulfill this important goal, we must prevent those who wish to disrupt our way of life from ever stepping foot on our soil.
I'm happy to hear that President George H.W. Bush was released from the hospital today. We'll be keeping him and Barbara in our prayers as he continues his full recovery at home.

Obama's action to limit law enforcement access to life-saving equipment was truly disappointing and deeply saddening – and I'm continuing my aggressive fight to reverse his dangerous decision to place politics ahead of safety.   I've already urged President Trump to work with me on this important issue, and I'm very optimistic about the strides we'll make to ensure our officers are properly equipped to safely do their jobs. With all the sacrifices they make for us each day, we simply owe them nothing less.

PASSED: I'm happy to announce that another U.S.-Israel partnership bill (H.R. 612) I introduced passed the U.S. House this week. Similar to my legislation that was signed into law last year, it enhances our bond with our strongest and most strategic ally in the Middle East by boosting our cybersecurity collaboration efforts. With the rapidly increasing role cybersecurity plays in ensuring the safety and security of our citizens, I am glad we can partner together as we work to protect both our countries from malicious cyber actors and from those who intend to do us harm.
BREAKING: Great news for the Constitution and our country.

I want to thank and commend President Trump for nominating Judge Neil Gorsuch to continue serving our country as a Supreme Court Justice. Because despite how the media tries to polarize this nomination, this isn’t about partisan politics – rather, it’s ensuring we have a proven, respected jurist on the highest court in the land.  As a former U.S. Attorney, and even now as a Member of Congress – I’ve taken the very same oath Judge Gorsuch took to defend the Constitution. And I firmly believe we can all take comfort that his track record proves he takes this responsibility just as seriously as the American people expect and deserve.

This week I proudly voted to undo Obama's last-minute rule that threatened the Second Amendment rights of 4.2 MILLION Americans by targeting folks who have a designated payee for their social security benefits. I'm glad my House colleagues joined me in passing legislation overturn this clear violation of constitutional rights that was rushed through in the very last weeks of Obama's presidency, and I'm hopeful the Senate will quickly join us in taking action to stop it for good.

I'm glad the Trump administration has taken swift and immediate action against Iran's repeated ballistic missile launches and ongoing support of terrorism across the globe. Unlike the Obama administrations' passive acceptance of this defiant behavior, imposing new sanctions shows that we won't mess around when it comes to dealing with those who continually refuse to play by the rules. If we sit back and ignore these flagrant violations by the world’s largest state-sponsor of terror, we’d be ignoring the huge threat they pose to the safety of the American people and the rest of the free world.
Although I wish the Cowboys were playing, I'm glad we'll get to see President George H.W. Bush flip the coin before kickoff at tonight's big game.

With a Republican in the White House, what was impossible under President Obama now becomes possible. I'm incredibly optimistic about the future of my House-passed legislation to rein in the regulatory swamp that's plagued our country for far too long. After all, the election this November sent a clear message to Washington that the American people don’t want eight more years of the same, and Congress owes it to them to deliver on this mandate

Happy birthday to President Ronald Reagan! I will never forget the impact he had on me as a young high schooler, when I first had the privilege to hear him speak in person. His message of opportunity, optimism and hope, and his confidence that each American can go as far as their hard work will take them continues to inspire me to this day.

More good news for the Constitution: Trump's Supreme Court nominee has publically opposed the legal standard that's been giving unelected federal bureaucrats extra powers since 1984.   His position on this issue falls right in line with my Separation of Powers Restoration Act, which passed the U.S. House last month to help rebalance our federal government. It's about time we had more leaders like Gorsuch in Washington who agree it's time to rein in the sprawling regulatory branch that's been burdening hardworking American families for far too long.

Today I was honored to speak to law enforcement officers from all across the country at the Major County Sheriffs’ Association’s annual winter meeting. It was truly humbling stand in front of a room full of people, who I know from personal experience, make such enormous sacrifices day-in and day-out to keep our country safe.  I have incredible optimism about all we’ll be able to accomplish on behalf of law enforcement safety alongside President Donald J. Trump, who has already made it clear he’s committed to ensuring our police are properly equipped to safely do their jobs. While we can never fully repay them for all they do, I'll never stop fighting to do as much as we possibly can to show our gratitude for their great sacrifices.

#TBT: Last year, I questioned former U.S. Attorney General Loretta Lynch before Congress, and I was deeply disturbed that her testimony solidified the huge shadow that was cast upon the DOJ under the Obama administration. I'm so glad that as of yesterday, we officially have a new leader, Jeff Sessions, in this important role. I'm hopeful and optimistic that he will work diligently to restore the American people's trust in the DOJ.

I'm glad we now have a proven Obamacare opponent at the helm of the Department of Health and Human Services. Based off of Secretary Price's adamant stance against this disastrous law during his time in Congress, I'm very optimistic about the strong partner he'll be in his new role as we continue our work to repeal and replace it once and for all.

ICYMI: This week President Trump signed an executive order that confirmed he truly prioritizes law enforcement safety. Specifically, he required the review of nation's current laws to ensure they're working adequately to protect officers across the country. This gives me great hope in the ongoing strides we'll make with him in undoing the harmful impact of President Obama's actions to limit police access to life-saving equipment that I've been fighting so adamantly against in Congress.

ICYMI: Yesterday on KXII TV's Sunday show, I discussed my efforts alongside the Trump administration to reverse President Obama's actions that threatened law enforcement safety. When you look at attacks like those in Orlando or San Bernardino – it's clear that police are facing increasingly dangerous and life-threatening situations now more than ever before.   In fact, when terrorists strike, it's our state and local law enforcement officers who are often the first on the scene. It makes absolutely no sense to allow them to take on this immense duty left unprepared or unequipped, and I'm committed to continuing my fight to ensure they have access to what they need to safely do their jobs.

I've got a number of very sentimental items in my Washington, D.C. office – and I was proud to add a football helmet to this collection to commemorate Gunter High School's 2016 state football championship title. I’m highly impressed by the high level of talent and hard work this victory demonstrated on behalf of Texas’ 4th District, and I’m glad folks will get to see this special memento from back home when they come to visit. Congrats again to the entire team, coaching staff and school on this wonderful accomplishment.

Today I proudly voted for legislation that sent a clear message to our federal government: "Don’t mess with Texas." Thanks to the overreach and survey errors made by unelected bureaucrats at the Bureau of Land Management, folks who’ve been living on and maintaining a 116-mile stretch along the Red River didn’t know whether they’d have their land stripped away by Washington, D.C. I’m glad my Texas colleagues joined me in supporting the “Red River Gradient Boundary Survey Act” that passed the House today to put an end to this mess.

Yesterday President Donald J. Trump signed legislation I voted for to repeal a harmful Obama-era regulation that would have put Americans at a disadvantage against foreign competitors. This is the first of many Obama-era regulations Republicans in Congress have been working around the clock to undo, and I'm hopeful we'll be sending more bills like this to the White House very soon. The time to end overregulation is now.

IT'S OFFICIAL: Legislation I voted for in the U.S. House to reverse the Obama administration's last-minute assault on 2nd Amendment rights just made it one step closer to President Donald J. Trump's desk.
Proud to be teaming up with Senator Ted Cruz to take down Elizabeth Warren's brainchild: the disatrous CFPB.

This week, we celebrate Rep. Sam Johnson's "Returniversary” to Texas after he spent nearly seven years as a POW in the infamous "Hanoi Hilton" during the Vietnam War. Sam bravely endured 42 months of solitary confinement, 72 days in leg stocks, 2 ½ years in leg irons, and severe starvation.  His great sacrifice for our country earned him two Silver Stars, two Legions of Merit, the Distinguished Flying Cross, one Bronze Star with Valor, two Purple Hearts, four Air Medals, and three Outstanding Unit Awards – all of which can never equate to the suffering he went through on behalf of our freedom. Sam is a true American hero who should inspire us all.

ICYMI: Yesterday I voted for, and the U.S. House passed, legislation to overturn Obama's last-minute rule that would have prevented the ability of states to deny funding to abortion providers like Planned Parenthood. I've long been adamant and vocal about my staunch opposition to the federal government using taxpayer dollars in this way, and I'm glad my colleagues joined me in ensuring Texas won't be bullied into doing so either.

This week I was proud to support legislation that passed the U.S. House to to enhance services for veterans seeking assistance with compensation claims. It’s no secret that there’s a lot of work to be done to reform our country’s VA system, and I’ve been fighting aggressively to advance those efforts in Washington. But in the meantime, we’ve got to step up to the plate and fill in the gaps through the services provided on the local level, and that’s exactly what my staff is committed to doing.   I’ve been very pleased with incredible work my staff has done to serve veterans throughout our communities. With more than 63,000 veterans in Texas’ 4th District, this is no easy task, and I’m glad my colleagues in the U.S. House have joined me in passing legislation to streamline this important job as much as possible.

Over the last few weeks, I’ve supported 13 different bills to overturn Obama-era regulations – all of which have passed the House and are quickly being taken up in the Senate. President Trump has already signed two of these bills into law.   This is incredibly significant because prior to this week, this legislative tool to overturn regulations had only been successfully used once in our nation's history. I'm very encouraged by the progress we've made so far because this is how government is supposed to work: FOR the American people.

In just two weeks, 7-year-old Kaden Newton raised more than 10,000 food items for Rockwall County children. He was able to do this through his very own nonprofit called Mac & Cheese and Pancakes, which he founded to collect "kid-approved" food for children in his community who are in need. Kaden's commitment to serving others at such a young age is incredibly inspiring, and I'm grateful to see the positive impact his work is having on folks in Texas' 4th District.
Happy Presidents' Day!

Today I spoke on The Mark Davis Show about legislation Senator Ted Cruz and I introduced to abolish the Consumer Financial "Protection" Bureau or CFPB, which – contrary to its name – has actually hurt the very folks it was supposed to help. The CFPB is a "benevolent dictator" created by Sen. Elizabeth Warren that's killing jobs and not being held accountable to Congress. This is an affront to every tenet of American democracy, and it must end.

The harmful impact of Obamacare has been felt all across the country: premiums spiked by 25 percent last year, 18 out of 23 co-ops failed, 70 percent of counties now have only one or two insurance options, and major insurers have continued to drop out. Each of these symptoms reflects real harm being done to real people right here in Texas' 4th District, and I want to hear your stories. How has Obamacare impacted you and your family? Ready, GO.

On this day in 1945, one of the most iconic moments from World War II took place when five Marines and a Navy hospital corpsman proudly raised the American flag atop Mount Suribachi. America remains grateful for their brave service and for the service of all the men and women who've fought to keep our nation free throughout our history.

ICYMI: Last night, the Trump administration revoked the Obama administration's directive requiring public schools across the country to allow transgender students to use bathrooms of their chosen gender.   As I said when this action was first announced last May: the federal government has no role in regulating school bathroom use. This action was a blatant political stunt by the Obama administration, and I'm glad President Trump has moved swiftly to undo it.

One of the biggest drivers of overregulation under the Obama administration was the lack of accountability to the American people. I'm glad that President Trump has taken action to boost transparency at our federal agencies, so we can put a stop to the endless flow of unnecessary and burdensome regulations that have been churned out at an obscenely rapid pace for far too long.

This week I presented the John Ratcliffe Lone Star Award to 7-year-old Kaden Newton to recognize his efforts to launch his very own nonprofit called Mac & Cheese and Pancakes, which collects "kid-approved" food for children in need in Rockwall County. I'm very impressed by the enormous positive impact he's having on his community at such a young age.

I'd like to thank Alex Schultz for all of the hard work he's contributing as an intern in my Rockwall district office this semester. Alex is a graduate of Rockwall High School, and I'm grateful he's chosen to give back to his community by helping us serve the people of Texas' 4th District.

JOBS SAFE: Supporting the critical mission of the Red River Army Depot (Official) has always been one of my top priorities in Congress. That's why my staff and I worked tirelessly with the administration over the past few weeks to ensure that President Trump’s federal hiring freeze would not have the unintended consequence of negatively impacting job security for employees at the Depot. This past week, I was extremely glad when extensions for over 700 employees were approved by the Secretary of the Army. The Depot is a critical part of our national defense, and I will always fight for its success.
Tonight at 8pm CT President Donald J. Trump will give his first joint address to Congress. Make sure to tune in!

BREAKING: Today President Donald J. Trump signed an executive order against the Obama administration's harmful "Waters of the United States" (WOTUS) rule. This is the same thinly disguised "water cleanup measure" I voted against in Congress last year to get the federal government out of people's backyards, and I'm glad Trump has joined us in taking action against this blatant EPA power grab.

It was a privilege to attend President Trump’s first Joint Address to Congress. The President's message was powerful and optimistic. Last night, he made it clear that he will prioritize polices that foster opportunity for the American people instead of stifling it, and that he supports a vision for our country that puts the safety and security of our own people first.   What were your thoughts on his speech?

Not too long ago, Royse City Police Officer Alan Potter risked his life as he wrestled a handgun away from a man to prevent him from killing himself and two others. Brave actions like this are vital reminders of the immense courage it takes to put on a uniform and go into the line of duty each day to protect our communities. This is precisely why I've been committed to standing up for police all across Texas' 4th District and our entire country, and why I'm glad we now have a president who's made it clear he shares this important priority.
Happy Texas Independence Day!

In his Joint Address to Congress to Congress, President Donald J. Trump voiced his strong support for our nation's men and women in uniform. Share if you agree we owe the utmost respect to those who have fought and who currently fight to defend our freedom.
Congratulations to former Texas Gov. Rick Perry on being confirmed as President Trump’s energy secretary. I’m looking forward to what a good dose of Texas values will bring to our new cabinet.

ICYMI: This week, I was proud to vote for legislation that passed the U.S. House to drastically cut back on the many thick layers of overbearing and costly regulations in Washington. The Searching for and Cutting Regulations that are Unnecessarily Burdensome (SCRUB) Act will accomplish this by establishing an official commission to identify egregious and ineffective regulations, so we can begin wiping them out immediately. After eight years of rampant regulatory overgrowth under the Obama administration, it's about time we clean up shop.

This week, I told FOXNews.com why my House Judiciary colleagues and I recently approved legislation to remove the shadow of doubt cast over the DOJ under the Obama administration when billions of dollars were being illegally funneled to pet organizations and its political allies. The Stop Settlement Slush Funds Act would ensure this illicit abuse of taxpayer dollars won't ever be allowed to happen again.

I'm pleased that Secretary Ryan Zinke wasted no time reversing the Obama administration's last-minute lead ammunition ban on his first full day at the Department of Interior. This is a huge win for the Second Amendment and for  law-abiding Americans all across the country who would have been unfairly stopped from participating and hunting and fishing for recreation thanks to a blatantly obvious Obama-era political stunt.
On March, 6 1836, Mexican forces killed all of the Texan defenders at the Alamo. To this day, we still remember all those who lost their lives in this fateful battle.

TODAY: Providing for the common defense is the number one responsibility of the federal government, and I applaud President Trump’s new executive order for prioritizing this important goal. As a former terrorism prosecutor and member of the House Homeland Security Committee, I’ll continue working alongside the Trump administration to ensure American people are protected from terrorist threats.
On this day in 1901, the Texas legislature proclaimed bluebonnets as our state flower. Spring in Texas certainly wouldn't be the same without them.

ICYMI: Today I appeared on KXII-TV to discuss the bill I introduced with Senator Ted Cruz to repeal the Obama-era Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB). Rather than protecting consumers, the CFPB has hurt far too many farmers, ranchers, small-businessmen and hard-working folks all across Texas and our country since it was founded under President Obama's watch. I’m optimistic at our renewed chances of putting a stop to the CFPB's harmful impact with President Donald J. Trump now in the White House.

It was my honor to present the John Ratcliffe Lone Star Award to its youngest recipient ever, Kaden Newton. I created this award last year to recognize extraordinary constituents in Texas’ 4th District who selflessly help those in need, and Kaden certainly fits the bill.   Not only is it remarkable that he’s gone out of his way to create a charity called Mac & Cheese and Pancakes at such a young age – but his efforts have also been extremely successful. It’s wonderful to see work like this being done back home out of the goodness of people’s hearts.

In his recent joint address to Congress, President Trump said, “Obamacare is collapsing, and we must act decisively to protect all Americans. Action is not a choice, it is a necessity.” I couldn’t agree more.    As various iterations of Obamacare repeal and replace legislation are drafted and amended over the coming weeks, you can count on me to do what the Democrats failed to do back in 2009 – I'll actually read the bill BEFORE voting on it – and you can too.  We all know you shouldn't have to pass a bill to see what's in it. As we move forward with our important responsibility of repealing and replacing Obama's most disastrous law, you can count on me to examine each detail of our replacement plan with diligence. Words on paper have real impact on real people – a fact that I've always taken very seriously on YOUR behalf.

It's no coincidence that illegal border crossings have dropped drastically since President Trump took office. This is clear evidence that a strong and vocal commitment to actually enforcing our nation's immigration policies pays off. I’m looking forward to continuing my work alongside the Trump administration as we remain dedicated to restoring respect for the rule of law.

This week I voted to protect the Red River Army Depot (Official) and strengthen America’s military through the passage of the 2017 Defense Appropriations Act (H.R. 1301) in the U.S. House. The bill also included a 2.1 percent pay raise for our troops.  A strong and robust military is absolutely necessary for protecting the safety and security of the American people, and the Depot plays a critical role ensuring this important responsibility of the federal government is fulfilled. I’m always proud to support legislation that will advance both of these key priorities.
Happy birthday to Chuck Norris – the famous "Walker, Texas Ranger."

This week Texas A&M University-Commerce celebrated its 100-year anniversary. As the third largest institution in the A&M System, TAMU-Commerce plays an enormous role in educating folks here in Texas 4th District and beyond. I'm glad a member of my staff was able to attend the official celebration and groundbreaking ceremony.

Hillary Clinton represented an opposite path. She wanted to double down on Obamacare and set the stage for a European-style single payer system.  The American people rose up and said no. By electing a unified Republican government they signaled that the status quo was simply no longer acceptable. In the Fourth District of Texas, which I’m privileged to represent, the contrast was especially stark. More than 76 percent of people rejected Hillary Clinton’s dangerous path of doubling down on a broken law.  While repealing and replacing Obamacare won't be easy, I won't forget your clear demand. I was particularly pleased that our discussion led to the president’s support for creating optional Medicaid block grants; incentivizing the implementation of work requirements for able-bodied, non-disabled, childless adults; and preventing tax credits from being used to pay for elective abortions. Supporting state and local law enforcement has always been a top priority of mine in Congress, and this week, I introduced the Strengthening State and Local Cyber Crime Fighting Act of 2017 to help ensure this important goal is met.  We’ve all seen crime shows on TV where pieces of DNA evidence – a strand of hair or a drop of blood – solve the case. But in today’s world, we also have to consider digital evidence. This could be an email that was sent, an online purchase, or geolocation technology that places an individual at the scene of a crime.  Cyber elements add layers of complexity to the crimes our local law enforcement officers face every day – and we’ve got to make sure they have access to the training they need to address this trend. And that’s exactly what my bill aims to do.

This Police Week, I'm proud that the U.S. House is passing key legislation in support of law enforcement, including my bill, H.R. 1616, which authorizes a premier police training center located in my colleague, Congressman Gary Palmer's district in Hoover, Alabama. I was humbled for the opportunity to personally congratulate Jordan Soper-Johnson for accepting his nomination to attend West Point Military Academy. Considering all he's already achieved during his time at Hooks High School, I have no doubt he'll continue making Texas' 4th District proud as he embarks on this exciting new endeavor. We are grateful for his service to our country.

The young folks in Texas’ 4th District never cease to amaze me with their incredible talent and thoughtful creativity. We had a lot of great artwork submitted for this year’s art competition, and I’m grateful for all who participated. I’d like to congratulate Brittany Ables for taking home the victory – we’re looking forward to having her artwork displayed in our nation’s capital.
Happy Armed Forces Day! Thank you to all who have served or are currently serving our country.

PASSED THE HOUSE: I've been very humbled by the opportunity I've had to advance legislation to combat child exploitation along with my colleague, Trey Gowdy, through our work together on the House Judiciary Committee. As former federal prosecutors, we can both attest to the importance of my bill that passed the U.S. House today, which will help ensure that all dangerous sex offenders are properly punished. After all, we can talk all day long about fighting for the future of our country – but the reality is that our children are our future – and if we do anything here in Congress, it should be working to protect them.

Today I join you with a heavy heart in mourning over the grave and tragic terrorist attack that occurred in Manchester. My thoughts and prayers are with all whose lives were taken, and with their friends and loved ones, in the wake of this terrible tragedy.  This attack reaffirms the importance of our fight to eradicate terrorist groups who intend to inflict harm upon us, our neighbors and folks all across the globe. Right now, we stand with Manchester in solidarity – committed, together, to eliminating ISIS and violent Islamist extremism once and for all.

I'd like to congratulate Timothy Austin Duncan – from my own hometown of Heath, Texas – for graduating from the U.S. Coast Guard Academy this past weekend. As President Donald J. Trump said in his remarks at the graduation ceremony – Timothy and his fellow cadets deserve congratulations and gratitude from each and every citizen of our country.  On top of the prestige of being one of fewer than 200 cadets to graduate in the Coast Guard Class of 2017 – I'm impressed that Timothy's class served breakfast at the local food bank every single weekday, helped rebuild a home with Habitat for Humanity, and led cadets to donate more than 24,000 community service hours during their time at the Academy. America is very blessed to have these young leaders defending our freedom.

According to a new report, Texans have experienced a STUNNING 82 PERCENT INCREASE in Obamacare premiums since 2013.   Rather than being able to use their paychecks to put food on the table, save for their children's educations or plan for their retirement – families across Texas – and across the country – are being forced to funnel more and more of their hard-earned dollars into the failing disaster of Obamacare.   This is why I was proud to vote to repeal Obamacare and put conservative healthcare reforms in its place. I refuse to sit idly by and watch it crumble under its own weight while punishing far too many hardworking families on its way down. The folks I represent in Texas' 4th District deserve better – and the American people deserve better.

Today I voted for the House passage of the Reducing Regulatory Burdens Act of 2017 to roll back yet another Obama-era regulation. This measure reverses an unnecessary EPA rule that required farmers and local health officials using pesticides to obtain a duplicative and expensive permit under the Clean Water Act – even though such pesticide use was already regulated under existing law. I'm very grateful we've now got an administration in office that will help us in peeling back these layers of red tape.

I'd like to congratulate Rockwall Lacrosse for taking home the Texas High School Lacrosse League Division II championship title. I’m very proud that the young folks of Texas' 4th District continue to stand out on a statewide level with their impressive talent and accomplishments.

ICYMI: As a former federal prosecutor, I'm absolutely sickened that loopholes in our current laws leave the door wide open for sex offenders to evade proper punishment for their horrific crimes against children. That's why I'm very grateful the U.S. House passed my bill, the Strengthening Children's Safety Act, this week to put an end to this inexcusable problem in our country's legal system.

In preparation for more Memorial Day, more than 280,000 U.S. flags were placed in front of headstones at the Arlington National Cemetery yesterday. I'm hopeful that everyone will be able to take a moment to honor America's fallen heroes this holiday weekend and reflect of the great sacrifice made by the brave men and women who've given their lives on behalf of our freedom.

We wouldn’t have the chance to enjoy our great freedom as Americans if it weren’t for the sacrifices made by the brave men and women throughout our nation’s history who’ve fought so valiantly to protect it. That’s why I’m grateful for the special opportunity that Memorial Day provides for us to push pause on our busy lives, and express our gratitude for those who’ve given the ultimate sacrifice.  For every member of our military who’s given their life in defense of this great nation – there’s a mother or father who’s lost a child, an individual who’s lost a spouse or partner, or a child who’s lost a parent – today, let us also make sure to remember their great sacrifice. Today, as Americans, we come together to say thank you.

Last year, I launched the “Rising Lone Star Award" to recognize high school students in Texas’ 4th District who've stood out as role models and leaders at their schools by engaging in extraordinary acts of self-sacrifice or community service to help those in need.   I created this award because I firmly believe that it’s important to recognize those who’ve selflessly gone above and beyond to do something that might not always appear on a college application or resume. This year, I’m proud to have recognized almost 70 exceptional students throughout the hundreds of ISDs in Northeast Texas whose impressive accomplishments reinforce my optimism about the future of our country.

Like you, I watched these last eight years as, time and time again, President Obama abandoned out ally, Israel, in times of need while pacifying state sponsors of terror, like Iran. This lead from behind strategy was wrong. It was dangerous. And with President Trump, I’m happy to report that it is over.   In his very first trip abroad as President of the United States, I was pleased that President Trump visited Israel to reaffirm America’s unwavering commitment to this strategic partnership. No longer will the United States agree to dangerous foreign policies like Obama’s Iran Nuclear Deal that I voted against. And no longer will the United States sit back idly and allow and allow the UN to pass resolutions that fly in the face of our historic support of our closest ally and friend  As Prime Minister Netanyahu said, and President Trump confirmed, we can now shift our collective focus back to advocating for policies that will deter Iran’s aggression and stop their promotion of terror. And we can now leverage our strategic partnership to defeat the threats posed by radical Islamist extremism.

I was pleased for the chance to personally congratulate Nathaniel Peek of Rockwall for accepting his appointment to attend West Point Military Academy. It was wonderful to see the strong support he has from his family and community, as he will soon embark on this exciting new journey. We are very grateful and proud to have another young leader from Texas' 4th District stepping up to serve our country.

It was truly a humbling experience to pay my respects to our fallen heroes yesterday at the Afghanistan - Iraq Memorial Wall for Texas as it made its way through Texas' 4th District. This special memorial honors all the brave men and women from Texas who've given their lives in service to our country during the Global War on Terrorism.   At this ceremony, I had the opportunity to meet Fay West whose son, Tracy, was killed in Iraq in 2004. Words cannot express how grateful we are for his great sacrifice and for the sacrifices of all those who've laid their lives on the line on behalf of our freedom.

It was my pleasure to nominate and to personally congratulate Trey Jones of Van Alstyne for being accepted to the US Air Force Academy (Official). Given that only 13 percent of applicants are accepted to this very prestigious military academy, it is incredibly exceptional that both Trey and his twin brother, Will, have been selected to attend. Their high level of success and dedication to serving our country should make everyone in Texas' 4th District proud.

According to a newly released report, the Obama administration issued a record number of new regulations on its way out the door in 2016, leaving an administrative state that saps the economy of nearly $2 trillion a year.   This just reaffirms the importance of anti-regulatory measures, such as the House-passed Separation of Powers Restoration Act and ALERT Act I introduced, which aim to cut back on the sprawling layers of costly red tape that grew out of control under former President Obama's watch.  Additionally, I'm happy to report that over the past few months Congressional Republicans have successfully worked with President Trump to fully repeal many of the most harmful regulations rammed through by Obama on the way out of the door.

The pervasiveness of terrorist threats beyond the Middle East was evidenced yet again last week, when Britain experienced the deadliest terrorist attack on its soil since 2005. This horrific event demonstrated precisely why my colleagues and I in Congress have been sounding the alarm on the very real dangers that can stem from ISIS’ ongoing efforts to radicalize people across the globe without ever crossing physical borders.   The ability to rapidly disseminate information online has enabled ISIS-inspired attacks to become increasingly prevalent outside of the Middle East – and we are quickly approaching the alarming 200-mark for ISIS-linked plots in the West. Now, more than ever, we must continue moving forward on legislation that will ensure we can finally put a stop to the rapid spread of terrorism across the globe.
God bless Texas. And God bless this great country.

I hope everyone is having a blessed Sunday. Please join Michele and me in praying for the U.K. as it recovers from another terrorist attack. We must all stand up united against Islamist extremism and the threat it poses to all of humanity.

Today marks the 75th anniversary of the Battle of Midway - a key turning point in World War II. God Bless the brave men and women who have sacrificed so much to keep our country safe. Giving our military the tools and resources it needs to succeed remains one of my top priorities in Congress.

Last week, I had the pleasure of touring the Eaton production floor in Sherman. As I said to the folks I met with that day, this where the pro-business, pro-growth legislation I vote for in Washinton really makes an impact. It was great to get a glimpse of the day-to-day operations of the facility and to speak with the employees about the the policies I support on their behalf.

On the anniversary of D-Day, let us take a moment to express our eternal gratitude for the incredible bravery of those who stormed Normandy and gave their lives 73 years ago today.

Yesterday I went down to Hoover, Alabama to visit the law enforcement training center that my bill (H.R. 1616) recently passed the U.S. House to authorize: the National Computer Forensics Institute. I was very impressed by the incredible work being done at this facility to ensure that our United States Secret Service officers can effectively collaborate with their state and local counterparts to solve crimes in every jurisdiction – a task that’s become increasingly challenging in the digital age.

As a cosponsor of the Stop Settlement Slush Funds Act, which sought to end this very practice, I'm extremely pleased in this huge step forward in removing the shadow of doubt that was cast over the DOJ under the Obama administration.

It was great visiting with students from Hooks ISD and Red Lick ISD on the steps of the U.S. Capitol Building today. I enjoyed speaking to them about our country's rich history and about what I'm doing in Washington for the people back home in Northeast Texas.

BREAKING: Today I voted for the House passage of legislation to repeal sweeping harmful Obama-era financial regulations created under the Dodd-Frank Act. Ever since Dodd-Frank was passed by a Democratic Congress back in 2010 as a knee-jerk reaction to the financial crisis – it’s been wreaking havoc on the people of Texas’ 4th District and all across the country.  I was proud to join my conservative House colleagues in passing our Republican plan – the Financial CHOICE Act – to revitalize our economy through LESS government and MORE freedom. The bill we just passed says goodbye to the suffocating overreach of government mandates and unelected bureaucrats, and it comes to the rescue of Main Street America.

I'd like to congratulate all of the high school students who were selected as our 2017 Rising Lone Stars for Texas' 4th District. This week I presented Amanda Condon of Texarkana with a flag flown over the U.S. Capitol when she was in Washington for the 2017 National Dreams to Success Awards. I am incredibly inspired by her hard work as a student, which has also earned her back-to-back Cola-Cola New Century Scholarships.   Amanda graduated from UAHT in spring 2016 with an Associate of Arts Degree. She is now senior at Arkansas Tech University, where she is pursuing a degree in Emergency Administration Management. I am certain her future endeavors will continue making Texas' 4th District proud.

One year ago today, 49 innocent lives were lost in the Orlando terrorist attack. We will never forget the victims of this terrible tragedy and why we must remain dedicated to the fight against terrorist threats on our own soil and around the world.
Wishing a happy birthday to 41!

THIS JUST IN: I'd like to congratulate my friend and colleague, Trey Gowdy, on being appointed as the new chairman of the House Oversight Committee. His broad experience and dedication to justice make me very confident in his ability to serve the American people well in this important role.

Today I proudly voted to send legislation on behalf of our nation's veterans to President Trump's desk.   As an American who owes my freedom to the men and women who’ve bravely fought so hard to defend it – I'm sickened when I’m reminded of those who died while waiting to receive care at the VA – and the many more who remained sick as their names sat idly on secret waiting lists.   That's why I'm incredibly glad we've passed the Department of Veterans Affairs Accountability and Whistleblower Protection Act of 2017, which will help ensure proper care for veterans. This measure expedites the ability to remove, demote or suspend VA employees for poor performance or misconduct that can place our veteran’s access to care in jeopardy, while also expanding protections for whistleblowers who seek to stop such abuse.  I’m very glad this bill has passed in both chambers of Congress, and I’m looking forward to President Trump’s strong support once it arrives on his desk.

We should all be grateful to the heroic response by the Capitol Police. I will continue to monitor the situation and share updates as they become available.

I hope everyone is having an enjoyable Father's Day. I feel so incredibly blessed today and every day to be the father of my two wonderful daughters, Riley and Darby.

And over the past few months, I'm proud that my conservative colleagues and I have made historic strides in doing just that – even against a strong headwind of obstructionists. I was glad to receive a positive update on one of our talented military academy students, Jack Neal , who graduated from Savoy High School last year. He will then return to the U.S. Naval Academy for his sophomore year to continue pursuing his degree in atronaughtical engineering. He is certainly making Texas' 4th District proud!

Following the news of Otto Warmbier's death last night, I join the rest of our nation in prayer for his family, friends and loved ones. We must hold those who are responsible for such horrific treatment of American citizens accountable for their barbaric actions.

I’d like to congratulate Channing Davis of Atlanta, Texas for accepting his nomination to attend the US Air Force Academy (Official). Channing has completed one year of USAFA Prepatory School and will report to the US Air Force Academy later this month. He plans to major in mechanical engineering, possibly attend medical school, and to apply to fly HH-60 search and rescue helicopters. His willingness to serve our country is truly inspiring, and I look forward to seeing what he accomplishes in the future.

It was great having Grayson County Judge, Bill Magers, in DC today to engage in discussions about the local issues facing folks back home in Northeast Texas. This engagement between local and federal officials is key to ensuring the priorities of Texas' 4th District are always addressed in the work I'm doing here in Congress.

I was happy to hear that Main Street Texarkana has received national accreditation for 2017 under the Main Street American program. It's very encouraging to see ongoing commitment to preservation-based economic development and community revitalization in communities all throughout Texas' 4th District.

I had a great time at the annual White House Congressional Picnic with Michele and the girls tonight. It was nice to enjoy the evening together along with my fellow members of Congress and to get a moment to chat with Vice President Mike Pence and his wife, Karen.

BREAKING: President Donald J. Trump signed important legislation into law today, which I voted for in Congress, on behalf of our nation's veterans. This is the toughest legislation we've passed yet to deliver much-needed reforms to our VA and help ensure proper care for veterans.   When implemented, it will expedite the ability to remove, demote or suspend VA employees for poor performance or misconduct that can place our veterans’ access to care in jeopardy, while also expanding protections for whistleblowers who seek to stop such abuse.  Not only is this new law a huge win on for our nation’s veterans – but it also serves as a key example of our federal government working the way it was intended, and this makes me optimistic about the ongoing success we’ll have as we continue fighting for the American people.

It was busy and productive week in Washington, as I spent time marking up key legislation in the House Judiciary Committee, discussing my efforts to bolster America's cybersecurity posture, and meeting with folks about the important issues facing Texas' 4th District. Every day is a privilege to serve the folks of Northeast Texas, and I'm very grateful for the incredible progress being made on your behalf.

BREAKING: Today the U.S. Supreme Court struck down Missouri's decision to prevent a church-operated daycare and preschool from receiving funding from a state program. This ruling made it clear that the government can’t block religious organizations from participating in public safety programs solely because they are religious — a major win for religious freedom and the Constitution.

A little over a year ago, a volunteer firefighter from my district and his two children – just 4-years and 22-months old – were killed in a tragic car accident caused by a previously-deported illegal alien. This week, the House is scheduled to vote on two key bills – the No Sanctuary for Criminals Act (H.R. 3003) and Kate's Law (H.R. 3004) – which will both target illegal immigration and help prevent such terrible tragedies from happening again in the future.   My thoughts and prayers remain with all of the families who've fallen victim to the serious – and sometimes fatal – consequences caused by the failure or outright refusal to enforce our nation's laws immigration laws. I'm glad my House colleagues are joining me in taking action to ensure the rule of law is properly enforced.

Today I'm joining the House Republican weekly press conference to discuss two key bills the House will vote on this week, Kate's Law and the No Sanctuary for Criminals Act, which aim to strengthen the enforcement of our immigration laws and enhance Americans' safety.

This is the same thinly disguised "water cleanup measure" I voted against in Congress last year to get the federal government out of people's backyards. I was pleased to welcome this year's Congressional Art Competition winner, Brittany Ables of Rockwall High School, to our nation's capital today. I'd like to congratulate James Mincey, a Vietnam veteran and Purple Heart recipient, for receiving the Texoma Hero Award. I join the entire 4th District of Texas in gratitude for his service to our country and his ongoing efforts help out other veterans in his community by offering support to those struggling with PTSD, addiction or other needs.

I'm always encouraged by the positive community involvement of folks in Texas' 4th District through events like yesterday's Annual David Dickson Memorial Fishing Friday. It's great to see our local children having the fun opportunity engage with the police officers who work so hard to keep them safe each day, and I'm glad a member from my staff was able to attend.

And just this week, I’m glad to report that the U.S. House of Representatives followed suit with two key bills on the federal level: Kate's Law and the No Sanctuary for Criminals Act.   At the end of the day, we can all be united by the common goal of enhancing the safety of the American people, and I'm very grateful for the strong support of the Trump administration in advancing this important fight.

I'd like to congratulate Jamie Hall, a 2017 Rockwall High School graduate, for being recognized as a National Merit Scholarship winner. With her scholarship, she plans to attend Southern Methodist University in the fall of 2017, and pursue a degree in biology.

As we celebrate Independence Day, I want to take a moment to thank every man and women who has served or is currently serving our country to defend our freedom – we are eternally grateful. Today, and every day, I’m proud to be an American – and I’m grateful for the opportunity you all have given me to represent the priorities of the 4th District of Texas in Congress. May God bless you all, and may God bless America.
Want to thank the dedicated law enforcement helping to ensure everyone's Fourth of July was safe.

I'd like to extend my warmest congratulations to Sheriff Harold Eavenson for being officially sworn in as the National Sheriffs' Association's president for 2017 to 2018. ICYMI: Last week I voted for the passage of the Refugee Program Integrity Restoration Act (H.R. 2826) in the House Judiciary Committee. This legislation boosts our national security through key reforms to our refugee program, which aim to curb fraud and bolster public safety. This week, I was pleased to present the “Lone Star Award” to Andy Mitchell for coordinating the purchase of a car for a stranger who was walking a total of six miles every day to and from work.   Last month, Andy, a local business owner from Rockwall, stopped to give a ride to a man who was walking on the side of the road. Upon discovering the man was walking three miles to work and back from his home each day, Andy reached out to his friends and other local business owners in Rockwall to fund the purchase of a car for him, as well as maintenance and fuel for an entire year.   I launched the "Lone Star Award" as a way to recognize significant actions of kindness and compassion in the Fourth District of Texas, and Andy's work to help a stranger in need epitomizes the Texas spirit that I want to highlight in our communities. I am very humbled to represent selfless constituents who go out of their way to make a positive impact in the lives of others.
One year ago today, the lives of five police officers were lost in a fatal ambush in downtown Dallas, including Brent Thompson of Royse City, Texas. We are eternally thankful for their service.

Last week, I was proud to join in the celebration of the new jobs that they're bringing to Texas' 4th District.

ICYMI: As a strong defender of the Constitution, I refuse to sit back and ignore any actions that may infringe on the religious liberties it protects. That's why I joined 63 of my Republican colleagues to reaffirm the strong constitutional prohibition against religious tests for public office. After all, the freedom of religion is a fundamental human right – and that means the government has no business imposing any fear of punishment for those who exercise that right as they so choose.

Today my thoughts and prayers have remained with all who were impacted by the tragic crash in Mississippi last night. I send my deepest condolences to the families of the service members who gave their lives in service to our country.

Chris is taking flying lessons as he aspires to become a pilot in the Air Force, which will mean he'll serve for 12 years upon graduation from the Academy. I'm very grateful for his selfless dedication to defending our freedom.

The American people are tired of the overregulation that crept into seemingly every aspect of their lives under the Obama administration, and I proudly support rolling back the many invasive rules that have been making their lives harder single every day.

I'm glad we're one step closer toward ensuring that the regulatory abuses of the Obama administration are put to a stop for good.

Wishing a happy Bastille Day to our friends in France!

As we're continually faced with the serious threats posed by radical Islamist extremism and burgeoning nuclear powers like North Korea, providing our military with the best training and defense capabilities in the world isn’t an option – it’s a necessity. I was proud to support this important legislation that will ensure we do just that.

I'm glad that a member of my staff was able to present retired District Clerk Billy Fox with a flag flown over the U.S. Capitol to thank her for 51 years of dedicated service to Bowie County. OBAMACARE REPEAL MUST CONTINUE:  Several months ago, I joined other conservative colleagues in the House and voted to repeal Obamacare. During our process of drafting the legislation, I was grateful to have a seat at the table meeting with President Trump to push through constructive, conservative reforms. National US&R teams, located across the United States, are trained and equipped to handle structural collapses and swift water rescues.  State and local officials are asking those in the impacted area to please remember:  Stay calm, do not panic.  Do not go into your attic – rescuers from the air cannot see you. Safely seek higher ground if able to do so; get to a safe place. Safely mark your roof to be seen by the air. To get rescuers’ attention, wave sheets, towels etc.  If you feel your life is in danger, call 911. First responders are not responding to requests for assistance received through social media, so if you cannot get through to 911 at first, keep calling.  The U.S. Coast Guard (USCG) has also stated that if you are in need of immediate rescue you can call them at the following numbers:  281-464-4851 281-464-4852 281-464-4853 281-464-4854 281-464-4855  The Coast Guard has over 420 personnel conducting operations in south Texas, with 16 helicopters in the air and 8 more inbound. As of 3 p.m. EDT today, the Coast Guard has confirmed rescues of more than 2,000 multi-person cases in the Houston-Galveston area.  The Coast Guard also has an additional nine teams onsite doing shallow water rescues. More information on USCG rescue operations is available on their website at: http://www.news.uscg.mil/Texas/.
